rule.name: or
rule.example: Let's choose A or B.

rule.name: or
rule.example: Let's choose A or B.

rule.name: Tag numbers
rule.example: Ten dollars
10 dollars

rule.name: Tag number-based adjectives
rule.example: This is the 22nd place.
The 99th conflict occurred yesterday.
... making it the 42nd most populous and 41st largest nation in the world.
This is the 33rd unscheduled repair this year.
1nd place
1 dollar
The 22nd is a good day for me.
You must go to London on the 22nd of the month.
Refer to the 22nd samples.
There are too many problems. This is the 99th, and it's only Tuesday.
This is the 23rd example. (The abbreviation has the postag JJ.)

rule.name: Disambiguate time
rule.example: It's ten past six.

rule.name: Disambiguate time no. 2
rule.example: It's half past six.

rule.name: so + adj/rb => so/RB
rule.example: He checked carefully, so that the mistakes were caught.
He checked so carefully.
Nothing can last forever.
Last Christmas I gave you my heart.

rule.name: 'sports' as adjective
rule.example: I enjoy winter sports.
Getting a sports car is easy.

rule.name: even now
rule.example: The even is approaching.
The rainbow mural persevered, even now, thirty years later.
The rainbow mural persevered, even now, thirty years later.

rule.name: first/last thing does not need an article
Remove POS NN:U from adjectives
rule.example: When you have a choice about which brush to use, use the large.
Use the large brush.

rule.name: Interjections
rule.example: Out!

rule.name: VB_OUT => not a verb
rule.example: He always left himself an out.
Go out!

rule.name: VB_EXCEPT => not a verb
rule.example: On Thursday nobody except Charlie Coe was thinking of Charlie Coe.
He insisted to except against a witness.

rule.name: except do => verb
rule.example: Nobody was perfect except him.
There was nothing he could do except jump into the ditch.

rule.name: go + verb/nn => verb
rule.example: I told him, I want to go see the Buck house.

rule.name: go ape => NN:UN
rule.example: Here is an ape.
He goes ape.

rule.name: go to + noun without determiner =>NN:UN
rule.example: Let's go to school.

rule.name: hat in hand => no determiner required
above/below ground => no determiner required
rule.example: The restaurant was below ground.

rule.name: at + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: We were at the university.
This happened at night.

rule.name: beyond + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: It's beyond your control.
It's beyond reach.

rule.name: beyond + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: It's beyond your control.
It's beyond description.

rulegroup.name: by + nouns that require no determiner

rule.example: She played chess with him by postcard.
She played chess with him by way of the WWW site.

rulegroup.name: for + nouns that require no determiner

rule.example: For example, he plays golf.
But I never sent them for fear of what I might find.
I followed it word for word.

rule.name: 'in as parts of proper names
rule.example: This was in his youth.
Ch'in dynasty

rulegroup.name: in + nouns that require no determiner

rule.example: In his youth, he was very young.
In summary, we might say that this argument is valid.
In his youth, he was very young.
In view of his weakness we might as well do nothing.
In his youth, he was very young.
Let's keep in touch with him.

rulegroup.name: on + nouns that require no determiner

rule.example: I'm always on time.

rulegroup.name: out of + nouns that require no determiner

rule.example: Control yourself!
Angela's life then spiraled out of control.
It's all out of kilter.

rule.name: under + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: No worries, it's under control.

rule.name: with + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: This includes issues that block access or interfere with access to the Web.

rule.name: without + nouns that require no determiner
rule.example: This is a war without end.

rule.name: look like - like => preposition
rule.example: I like the way he looks.
He looks like shit.

rule.name: kind of + adj/adv => no determiner required
rule.example: It's a kind of dogs.
I feel kind of stiff.
These two things are important.
These two bad things are important.
These are those bad two.
I have one black dog.
I have one dog.
No one trusts him any more.

rule.name: number + vbz/nns => nns
rule.example: One minute.
Figure two shows the results.
Although page 10 gives much information, it is incomplete.
If the number 5 shows on the display, stop the test.
Two and two makes four.
The debt of £3,000,000 harms the company's financial future.
If the growth rate we predicted in 2007 changes by more than two percent, ...
Although I agree with most points on the agenda, number two presents a challenge.
Most of these plants live in light places, but four lives in dark places.
It was twenty minutes.
These three tests show the problem.
Five samples are sufficient.
Those four ships were outstanding.

rule.name: No one as personal pronoun
rule.example: One car, two dogs, seven cats
No one trusts him any more.
No one trusts him any more.

rule.name: best as adjective
rule.example: I best my opponents.
It's best for him.

rule.name: Modal verb + verb/noun -> modal verb + verb
rule.example: He did not need man's testimony about man…
If you need oil, get a requisition order from your manager.
Will man ever reach the moon?
... but can oil be used instead of water?
Modal: ... and the can will be used repeatedly.
You can open your books now.

rule.name: do/did/does + verb/noun -> VB
rule.example: I did my homework.
What do Peter's parents do?
I did notice what you said.

rule.name: do/did/does + not + verb/noun -> VB
rule.example: I did my homework.
But do not Peter's parents agree with you?
I did not notice what you said.

rule.name: does + not = verb
rule.example: This does not happen.

rule.name: don't/didn't/doesn't + verb/noun -> VB
rule.example: I did my homework.
I didn't notice what you said.

rule.name: verb + well => well = RB
rule.example: It does integrate well.
I have a well.
It is well for us to remember.

rulegroup.name: in as noun -> in as preposition

rule.name: in as noun/preposition + the -> in as preposition
rule.example: Tom came in last.

rule.name: in as noun/preposition + uncountable noun -> in as preposition
in + adjective + noun
rule.example: The boss made him an in.
He's in perky form.

rule.name: the/these... + numeral + are (noun/verb) -> the... + numer + are (verb)
these + vbz/nns => nns
rule.example: These includes a razor blade.
Those clothes suit you well.

rule.name: these + vbz/nns => nns
rule.example: These includes a razor blade.
Those clothes suit you well.

rule.name: AM as NNP
rule.example: I AM HAPPY.
AM was the earliest modulation method.

rule.name: are (noun/verb) + adjective/gerund/preposition -> are (verb)

rule.name: Are...?
rule.example: One are of land.
Are people happy?

rule.name: Does...?
rule.example: One are of land.
Does he like me?

rule.name: NNS/VBZ + were/are

The armed forces are here.

rule.name: are + : + NNS

rule.name: committee/jury/class + VBP => NNS
rule.example: The jury is still out.
Traditionally, amphibians as a class are defined as all tetrapods with a larval stage.

rule.name: the/a + mine = mine (noun)

rule.name: during + verb 3sg.NNS =>NNS

rule.name: times as connective
rule.example: 4 times eleven equals 34.
These are hard times.

rule.name: times/addresses as noun pl

rule.name: times as noun pl

rule.name: means/verb + of =>noun

rule.name: mere means => noun

rule.name: adv/noun + verb -> adv
rule.example: It took them forever.
We supply parts to the auto manufacturer.[Adverb variant of 'supplely': https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/supplely]
Incorrect. Should be 'setback', but 'back' is not an adverb in this context. This set back is annoying.
You're forever making mistakes.

rule.name: as
rule.example: They are wed as gods.
He is as tall as my friend.

rule.name: as
rule.example: They are wed as gods.
He is as tall as my friend.

rule.name: as
rule.example: He is as tall as my friend.
They are wed as gods.

rule.name: better than
rule.example: This year's profits should better last year's by a wide margin.
She likes Hiroshima better than any other city.

rule.name: Possesive pronoun + verb/noun =>noun
rule.example: I do what I want to.
They should make up their minds!
Don't do anything against my will.

rule.name: Possesive pronoun + verb/noun + verb sing/modal => noun
rule.example: I do what I want to.
Make sure that your watering can does not have a hole.
Your singing puts professional singers to shame.
Her singing can shatter glasses!
Your dreaming will not change the world. Do something!
... and their fighting won't change the situation.

rule.name: Possesive pronoun + verb/adjective + noun sing => adjective
rule.example: I do what I want to.
Your loving friend

rule.name: Possesive pronoun + adj/noun =>noun
rule.example: I do what I want to.
Your two best boys.

rule.name: verb singular/noun + det + noun => verb
rule.example: This is work.
It has an advantage compared to objects that make something.
For more than one year there was updates every day.
... and there was weeds all round the grave.
Is marks all over the window your idea of cleaning?
The voices all die down slowly.
...of black pants with purple jersey made the Ravens the first NFL team to wear dark colors.
Gordon had his head in the clouds all week.
Hard work causes an event.

rule.name: verb singular/noun + noun plural or uncountable => verb
rule.example: This is work.
...is placed on top of the opening to support the bricks above.
... in the form of a buy and sell system with the tags taking the place of the more traditional...
... with Paul Jones and the Blues Society of Italian bluesman Guido...
... with DJ Hurricane to the AIDS benefit album 'No Alternative'.
The Gates family regularly went to services at...
In days past some used to color the eggs red, so as to show the kind of death by...
... because otherwise an arms race in this new technology would ...
These days more young husbands help their wives with housework.
There is also an arts and crafts industry that produces...
... if arts and crafts industries are thriving in that part of the country.
Hard work causes fitness.

rule.name: Adjective + verb singular/plural noun => noun
rule.example: I enjoy running.
Hard work causes fitness and vice versa.
This occurs when the core of a massive star exhausts its nuclear fuel.
I like military forces.

rule.name: Plural determiners + noun plur/vb sg => noun plur
rule.example: It depends whose hands it's in.
He hands it over.

rule.name: nouns in coordination
rule.example: Tickets are selling fast and space is limited.
Adjective: ... because it's free and support is not provided.
They are now man and wife duly married.
They were husband and wife.

rule.name: Prepositional quantifiers + noun plur/vb sg = >noun plur
rule.example: They cut a lot of hands.
He hands it over.

rule.name: most + verb in plural
rule.example: Most of his writing is rubbish.
Most are around 40-50 μm in diameter.

rule.name: less as connective (revenues less expenses)
rule.example: This is defined as indirect taxes less subsidies.
These batteries have less power.

rule.name: up to - not a noun
rule.example: We all have ups and downs.
What you're up to?

rule.name: right + away/now => RB
rule.example: You are right.
Do it right now!

rule.name: Is/was + it + verb/JJ =>JJ
rule.example: Is it Monday?
Is it true?

rule.name: make/get/do + it + verb/JJ => JJ
rule.example: Make yourself at home.
Join in, try it out, do it better!
You can do it better if you prioritize your work.
We thought it wrong to leave her alone.
Let's keep it simple.
Let's keep it clean.

rule.name: know/stand + xx + better => RBR
rule.example: We need to better the lot of the suburban commuter.
Later, you shall know it better.

rule.name: by + vbg → vbg
rule.example: It should be safe by then.
For now they are having fun and learning all they can by playing with neighbors and friends.
I'll by flying.

rule.name: free of charge
rule.example: Free yourself!
This is free of charge.

rule.name: even as a verb
rule.example: Even if you're right, we need to do this.
Even if you're right, we need to even out accounts.
Even if you're right, we need to do this.
Even if you're right, he wants to get even for the insult.
Even if you're right, we need to do this.
It even made an appearance at the Woodstock Music Festival.
Even if you're right, we need to do this.
It even made an appearance at the Woodstock Music Festival.

rule.name: long as JJ
rule.example: I long for you.
You should have completed it long ago.
You should have completed it long time ago.

rule.name: live as JJ
rule.example: I can live in Stockholm.
Tom has decided to live in Boston for the rest of his life.
He performed it live in Stockholm.

rule.name: still/further/long + verb = rb
rule.example: Still, I need to do a lot of things.
Much of the diet involved the use of peppers, as it still does today.

rule.name: a + rb/jj + nn => jj
rule.example: It still expands.
It was after a further investigation.

rule.name: best + verb = rb
rule.example: Still, I need to do a lot of things.
This best exhibits the features of the snake oil.

rulegroup.name: Phrases of the form similar to: step by step

rule.example: These are the steps you need to make.
Study it step by step.
Study it step by step.

rule.name: further as adjective
rule.example: Further Spanish attacks led by Hugo of Moncada in 1519 were harsh.

rule.name: forward as adverb
rule.example: She was a rude, forward child.
Push it forward!

rule.name: home as adverb
rule.example: Home, sweet home!
Maisha had brought it home.

rule.name: sort + of => not a verb
rule.example: I sort the entries in the dictionary.
But he sort of acted like he didn't care.

rule.name: I. as an abbreviation
rule.example: I am glad!
The I. A. P. A. is a reflection of the problems.

rule.name: I Ching
rule.example: I am glad!
But a tossing of coins, with perhaps the added safeguard of reference to the oracles of the I Ching, the Chinese Book Of Changes, dictates the handling of the chosen materials.

rule.name: You guys =>NNS
rule.example: You are fine.
You guys remember that.
It was a gift for he.
It is nice, for he does a lot of nice things.
It was a gift for he.
It is nice, for they do a lot of nice things.

rule.name: Do washing
rule.example: I like washing dishes.
They did washing.

rule.name: orders > noun
rule.example: These are my orders.
You cannot disobey orders!

rule.name: preposition + training =>noun
rule.example: I'm training now.
We need to to pay for training to meet national skilled manpower needs.

rule.name: will as modal verb
rule.example: This road will designated.
I will do it.
A person's will is an important document.
I was one who did not conform, and whose will could not be broken.
... and this will featured regularly in the lawyers' debates.
... control of thought, feelings and will combined with openness, tolerance and flexibility.

rule.name: noun/adj + noun => adj + noun
rule.example: This is a nice machine.
Is much powerful and wondrous magic necessary for Harry Potter to fly?
The circus will come to town tomorrow.
His party may have brought the disease with them from Egypt.

rule.name: Proper noun: Conference of Specialised Ministers
Proper noun: Organisation of Islamic Cooperation
Ignore spelling of superscripted units of measure

rule.example: Do a 4-Hour test.
Do a 3-wORd test.
Do a 3-secTIon test.
A 500-pages document is too large.
Do a 4-hour test.
Do a 3.5-hour test.
A 500-page document is too large.
This large (400-chapter) document is too large.
When you use an approved 2-word term, make sure that the ...
WRITE A 3-PAGE DOCUMENT.
A 10-person or possibly 11-person team is the optimum size.
We use a special 4-oil blend.
There is a 3-warning rule, which means that after 3 warnings, you will be dismissed.
The file is 30 GB.
A 30-Gb file is too large.
A 3-5-GB file is too large.
A 30-GB file is too large.
A 55.5-GB file is too large.
2.5-GB files and larger can ...

rule.name: the blessed
rule.example: Oh, the blessed fool really annoys me.
He also states that the blessed are called in Greek...
